metadata.sermon_title: The Love Olympics Go to Jerusalem
metadata.sermon_start_end: Two weeks ago there was a very funny little article in The New York Times Styles section about the fact that this year, for the first time in decades, Valentine’s Day fell on the Saturday of a three-day holiday weekend. [...] The love Olympics have gone to Jerusalem. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon attempts to link the Transfiguration (Luke 9) with the Hymn to Love (1 Cor 13). However, it treats the texts as illustrations of a 'generic' concept of love coming down, rather than mining the specific, unique content of the Transfiguration that can be found nowhere else. It uses the texts to support a thematic movement rather than letting the specific pericope dictate the logic.
quotes: The passage from I Corinthians is read today, not because somebody thought it would be nice to read for Valentine’s Day, but because it is about Jesus as he sets forth to be crucified.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on the specific details of the Transfiguration—the presence of Moses and Elijah and the specific content of their conversation—rather than using it as a transition to a general discussion on the nature of love.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is minimal technical exegesis. While the preacher correctly identifies Moses and Elijah as Law and Prophets, there is no engagement with the Greek text or the specific historical-theological context of Luke’s 'exodos' (departure). The requirement for Hebrew/Greek and deep context is largely ignored in favor of narrative retelling.
quotes: The appearance of Moses and Elijah ratifies the designation of Jesus as the Chosen One of Israel, the fulfillment of the Law (Moses) and the Prophets (Elijah).
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific meaning of 'exodos' in Luke 9:31 to show how this 'departure' is a unique fulfillment of Israel's history, rather than just a 'descent' from a mountain.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is the sermon's strongest point. It avoids 'general truths' by using very concrete, visceral contemporary examples: the Clinton scandal, Princess Diana, Martin Luther King Jr., and the grandmother of a dying child. It captures the 'zeitgeist' of the late 90s effectively.
quotes: How can we reclaim romance from a culture in which love-making is now a transaction to be described by Peeping Toms, recorded on tape, collected as DNA evidence...
I was aware of a lot of people standing around looking down at me. What I remember most about that long wait was the great distance between me on the concrete and the faces high above.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's uniqueness rather than from a general psychological need for 'closeness' or 'empathy'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon does not follow a 'first exegesis then application' structure; it weaves contemporary cultural commentary (Valentine's Day, Diana) into the reading of the text. However, the 'exposition' is so light that the 'application' often takes the lead, making the text serve the examples rather than the other way around.
quotes: It’s a good bet that most wedding guests hearing I Corinthians 13 understand it sentimentally... In actuality Paul’s words have nothing at all to do with romantic love.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Deepen the 'exposition' side of the mix so that the hearer is 'expounded' by the Word rather than just by the preacher's anecdotes.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' is vividly present in the descriptions of the dying child and the accident victim. 'Redemption' is found in Christ's descent into that misery. 'Gratitude' (the third part) is less developed, appearing only briefly as the call to become a disciple.
quotes: As Jesus of Nazareth sets his face toward Jerusalem, he is about to become in his own person the embrace of God for all the misery of all the world.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' section more robustly; how does this specific revelation of Christ's descent specifically shape the hearer's life beyond a general 'reaching out'?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is almost entirely absent. There is no sense of the 'two ways' or the possibility of being lost (temporal or eternal). The sermon is comforting and inclusive but lacks the 'seriousness of choice' Dekker demands. It assumes the hearer is already being 'embraced' without the tension of a 'narrow way'.
quotes: And whoever you are and whatever your pain... he reaches out, he comes down, to seek you, to find you, to embrace you.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'departure' in Jerusalem as a judgment on the 'broad way' of the world's power and the necessity of following Christ on the 'narrow way' of the cross.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is explicitly Christocentric. Christ is the 'telos'. It correctly identifies that 1 Cor 13 is a description of Christ. It emphasizes that salvation is 'outside ourselves' in the person of Jesus who descends.
quotes: It has often been noted that the famous Corinthian chapter on love really describes Jesus. He is the supreme model of mature love, today and forever.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Clarify the 'two natures' more sharply; emphasize that this 'descent' is not just a human moral example but the movement of God Himself.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1650 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 16-17 minutes. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true depth. The sermon feels more like a 'meditation' or 'address' than a full-scale exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic sections to reach the 20-minute threshold, allowing the text's own logic more room to breathe.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its lack of exegetical depth, its failure to address the 'two ways' (judgment/choice), and its insufficient length. It functions well as a contemporary cultural critique and a psychological comfort, but it treats the biblical text more as a thematic anchor than a unique, current, proclamatory Word of God that says something found nowhere else.
strengths: Concrete application that avoids religious jargon and addresses the contemporary zeitgeist directly.
Strong Christocentric focus, identifying Christ as the true subject of the biblical text.
Effective use of human psychology (misery) as a bridge to the Gospel.
weaknesses: Lack of technical exegesis (Hebrew/Greek/Context) as required by Dekker.
Absence of the 'two ways'—there is no warning or seriousness regarding being 'lost'.
Insufficient length to achieve the 'breadth' necessary for theological depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an 'adequate' address but not a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the formal rigor of exposition and the substantive weight of the 'two ways'. It is too short and too focused on 'general' psychological comfort to meet the high bar of the theses.
